claim: A 53-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-day history of fever and chills, severe malaise, and cough with yellow-green sputum. He works as a commercial fisherman on Lake Superior. Current medications include metoprolol and warfarin. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 96/min, respirations are 26/min, and blood pressure is 98/62 mm Hg. Examination shows increased fremitus and bronchial breath sounds over the right middle lung field. An x-ray of the chest shows consolidation of the right upper lobe. Which of the following is the most likely causal pathogen? : Mycoplasma pneumoniae

supporting.text: The patient's symptoms (fever, chills, malaise, productive cough) and chest x-ray findings (lobar consolidation) are classic for bacterial pneumonia, which is more commonly caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae than Mycoplasma pneumoniae.
